item.title: Report E-2025040550
item.description:
Report E-2025040550

Identified by scraper @ 2025-05-23T00:57:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-27
  • City: SALT LAKE CITY
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 0815ET, XPO-USU notified ERTS of a cargo release. It was reported that approximately 1 cup of Resin solution paint light blue released from a metal pail due to a forklift accident. The release impacted the concrete dock. Michael informed us that this was already cleaned up and placed into a 10-gallon drum. Reached out to Chemtrec for SDS. 231915-1 10-gallon metal drum - product, oil dri, brown paper bag. Chemtrec#2025032700062 was provided by Alex.

item.title: Report E-2025040292
item.description:
Report E-2025040292

Identified by scraper @ 2025-05-23T00:57:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-03-17
  • City: AMERICAN FORK
  • State: UT
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOLE TRANSPORT LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 25200
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver was loaded for store in Springville, UT. While on I-15 southbound lane the Driver struck a piece of road debris that was a metal rod at MM 275. Driver was in middle lane and could not avoid the object. When the object was struck it was thrown into his passenger side fuel tank on the truck creating a hole in this fuel tank. Driver pulled over to check the equipment and realized the fuel tank was leaking. Solar dispatched Environmental Restoration LLC to begin clean up. The diesel tank on the truck was full roughly 100 gallons released on the side of the I-15. Estimated 30 gallons impacted a drain along I-15 the other gallons stayed on concrete and was able to be collected via absorbent material. Environmental Restoration dispatched a Vac truck and Jet Rodder to clean the lines of the drain system. This clean up generated three 55-gallon drums of absorbent and impacted debris as well as the contents of the Vac truck.
